data.value: can be used to specify the corners of the quadrilaterals.

data.content:
`~.Axes.pcolormesh` is similar to `~.Axes.pcolor`. It is much faster
and preferred in most cases. For a detailed discussion on the
differences see :ref:`Differences between pcolor() and pcolormesh()
<differences-pcolor-pcolormesh>`.
data.name: hint

data.value: may be a masked array. If
is masked, the corresponding quadrilateral will be transparent. Masking of
The grid orientation follows the standard matrix convention: An array
with shape (nrows, ncolumns) is plotted with the column number as
Both methods are used to create a pseudocolor plot of a 2D array using quadrilaterals.
The main difference lies in the created object and internal data handling: While
. The latter is more specialized for the given purpose and thus is faster. It should almost always be preferred.
There is also a slight difference in the handling of masked arrays. Both
. The reason lies in the internal handling of the masked values.
leaves out the respective polygons from the PolyCollection.

sets the facecolor of the masked elements to transparent. You can see the difference when using edgecolors. While all edges are drawn irrespective of masking in a QuadMesh, the edge between two adjacent masked quadrilaterals in
is not drawn as the corresponding polygons do not exist in the PolyCollection.
Another difference is the support of Gouraud shading in
If given, all parameters also accept a string
Additionally, the following arguments are allowed. They are passed along to the

agg_filter: a filter function, which takes a (m, n, 3) float array and a dpi value, and returns a (m, n, 3) array alpha: array-like or scalar or None animated: bool antialiased or aa or antialiaseds: bool or list of bools array: (M, N) array-like or M*N array-like capstyle:
or {'butt', 'projecting', 'round'} clim: (vmin: float, vmax: float) clip_box:
clip_on: bool clip_path: Patch or (Path, Transform) or None cmap:
or str or None color: color or list of rgba tuples edgecolor or ec or edgecolors: color or list of colors or 'face' facecolor or facecolors or fc: color or list of colors figure:
gid: str hatch: {'/', '\\', '|', '-', '+', 'x', 'o', 'O', '.', '*'} in_layout: bool joinstyle:
or {'miter', 'round', 'bevel'} label: object linestyle or dashes or linestyles or ls: str or tuple or list thereof linewidth or linewidths or lw: float or list of floats norm:
picker: None or bool or float or callable pickradius: float rasterized: bool sketch_params: (scale: float, length: float, randomness: float) snap: bool or None transform:
url: str urls: list of str or None visible: bool zorder: float

A Colormap instance or registered colormap name. The colormap maps the
The Normalize instance scales the data values to the canonical colormap range [0, 1] for mapping to colors. By default, the data range is mapped to the colorbar range using linear scaling.

Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries.
Rasterize the pcolormesh when drawing vector graphics.  This can speed up rendering and produce smaller files for large data sets. See also

An alternative implementation with slightly different features. For a detailed discussion on the differences see
